title: Simone Biles’s Future at the Olympics Left Unclear

content: TOKYO — Simone Biles, the four-time Olympic gold medalist, came into the Tokyo Games as the headliner propped up by NBC and sponsors like Visa as a can’t miss star of the show. source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall and Isabella Kwai
title: Londoners Were Promised a Hill With a View. They Got a Pile of Scaffolding.

title: Nursing Homes May Face Steeper Safety Fines
description: The Biden administration has quietly undone a Trump policy that severely restricted penalties imposed on facilities that violated safety standards.
content: As the Delta variant raises fresh concerns about the safety of the nation’s nursing homes, the Biden administration has quietly reversed a controversial Trump policy that had limited the fines levied on facilities that endangered or injured residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Quarantined Dutch athletes allowed 15 minutes of fresh air after protest.
description: Some of the athletes said that coronavirus restrictions prevented them from going outside. Now they can get 15 minutes in front of an open window.
content: The quarantine measures at the Tokyo Games have come under scrutiny in recent days, with members of the Dutch delegation criticizing the restrictions for those who have tested positive for the coronavirus, including not being allowed to go outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg and Eliza Shapiro
title: As Delta Variant Spreads, N.Y.C. Parents Worry About Coming School Year
description: So far, there have been very few cases in New York City’s summer school session, but some parents want a remote option for the fall.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marion Renault
title: These Could Be the Oldest Animal Fossils Ever Found, or Just Squiggles
description: Critics challenged a study’s claim that a netlike structure found in rocks in a Canadian mountain range could be an 890-million-year-old sponge fossil.
content: A spongelike structure discovered in exposed 890-million-year-old rock in Canada’s Northwest Territories may be the oldest known fossilized animal body, according to a study whose findings will likely add another controversy to longstanding debates about the planet’s earliest animal life.

content: Joey Jordison, the founding drummer for the ghoulishly theatrical metal band Slipknot, who helped write many of the group’s best-known songs and often performed wearing a crown of thorns and a silver mask streaked with black paint, died on Monday. He was 46.

title: There Is No Good Reason You Should Have to Be a Citizen to Vote

But for me and my fellow noncitizens, it is a fact of political life that we submit to unquestioningly year after year, primary after primary, presidential election after presidential election. Nearly 15 million people living legally in the United States, most of whom contribute as much as any natural-born American to this country’s civic, cultural and economic life, don’t have a say in matters of politics and policy because we — resident foreign nationals, or “aliens” as we are sometimes called — cannot vote.

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Best Thing to Eat When It’s Hot
description: In paneer con tomate, bright and juicy acidity finds a perfect partner with bites of fried cheese.
content: Summer in Los Angeles, and the box grater, which I hang on an S hook with my pots and pans, gradually becomes my most precious kitchen tool. Not a knife, not a fancy pan, not a gadget I ogled in someone else’s kitchen, just that plain steel box grater with the horribly sharp handle that digs into my hand if I grip it too tightly, leaving a mark. But until tomato season ends, I grate every tomato I can: the bumped and bruised beefsteaks, half off at the grocery store, and the delicate heirlooms warmed by the sun at the farmers’ market. The ones I forget about and find again on the counter, soft, obscenely juicy and threatening to leak. The dark, almost purple tomatoes that ripen in my backyard — if I can get to them before the squirrels and the birds. At the grater, every tomato is the same: I make it a game to not waste a single bit of meat, to push my palm right against the metal and get down to a fine, translucent skin that curls at the edges.

title: After a Long Lockdown and Vaccination Campaign, Is England on the Road to Normality?
description: A downward trend in coronavirus cases that followed the lifting of most social-distancing rules is raising hopes that the worst is over, although the cause of the drop is not yet completely clear.
content: LONDON — For the past week, it has been the most eagerly awaited number in the land, posted each day at 4 p.m. by the British government. title: ‘Grandmother, Where’d You Get So Smart?’ ‘Living, Baby. Living.’
description: A woman with little formal education taught her granddaughter an important lesson.
content: I don’t come from a line of people who value traditional education. Trade school and the military are, to them, more viable options, and I bucked that tradition by being the first person in my family to go to college. Then again, spending nearly every afternoon after school with my grandmother, that’s hardly surprising — she’s seldom without a book.

author: By Carl Zimmer, Apoorva Mandavilli and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Citing New Data, Pfizer Outlines Case for Booster Shots
description: Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine may become slightly weaker over time, the company reported. But experts said that most people won’t need boosters anytime soon.
content: Pfizer reported on Wednesday that the power of its two-dose Covid vaccine wanes slightly over time, but nonetheless offers lasting and robust protection against serious disease. The company suggested that a third shot could improve immunity, but whether boosters will be widely needed is far from settled, the subject of heated debate among scientists.

content: LOS ANGELES — In the state that perfected if not invented the American summer, the smell of 17 million gallons of spilled sewage lingered last week on a Southern California beach. But sometimes, it’s just too hot or the day’s too long to even consider turning on an oven or stove. author: By Sophie Bew
title: In the English Countryside, a Library of Geraniums
description: At her home in Gloucestershire, the founder of the British sustainable luxury brand Daylesford Organic has nurtured her obsession with a single flower.
content: The amateur gardener could be forgiven for using the term “geranium” incorrectly, says Steve Gamble, one of a team of eight plantsmen who tend to the walled kitchen garden on the 2,500-acre Daylesford estate in Gloucestershire, England. The plant commonly known as a geranium, he explains, is actually a pelargonium, a different genus entirely. “It’s very confusing. You see that big purply thing up there,” he says, pointing to a wild, bushy plant with pansy-shaped lilac-colored flowers growing against the golden limestone wall of a nearby cottage. “That’s a geranium. They’re hardy — completely unlike these,” he continues, gesturing to the thousands of fuzzy-leaved, woody-stemmed pelargoniums with pink and white flowers that surround us. It’s a hot July day and we’re standing in a large and slightly clammy greenhouse that contains more than 120 pelargonium species, a collection that belongs to Lady Carole Bamford, the founder of the pioneering British brand Daylesford Organic.

title: We’re Ben and Jerry. Men of Ice Cream, Men of Principle.
description: We support the company's decision to end the sale of its ice cream in the occupied Palestinian territories.
content: We are the founders of Ben & Jerry’s. We are also proud Jews. It’s part of who we are and how we’ve identified ourselves for our whole lives. title: Vicky Krieps Gave Hollywood One More Try. It Wasn’t So Bad.

content: RAMBROUCH, Luxembourg — Four years ago, Vicky Krieps seemed destined for Hollywood stardom. The Luxembourgian actress had emerged from near obscurity to star in Paul Thomas Anderson’s “Phantom Thread,” in which she portrayed the tormented muse of a domineering fashion designer played by Daniel Day-Lewis. Her performance — vulnerable, prickly, anguished — garnered critical raves and suggested the arrival of a major new talent.

title: ‘Sex Talks’ Should Start Earlier Than You Think
description: Some parents feel awkward and reluctant to discuss bodies, consent and sexuality; their kids pay the price.
content: When a friend of mine took her kids to the pediatrician’s office a few weeks ago, her 7-year-old daughter noticed a birth-control poster and asked her about it. Soon after, her 4-year-old son began peppering her with sex questions too: “But Mom, why would a penis ever go into a vagina? Did Dad put his penis into your vagina?”

content: SEOUL — When South Koreans logged on to a government website this month to book Covid-19 vaccine appointments, a pop-up window told them there was “just a bit” of a delay.

title: To Sprinters, Hot Weather in Tokyo Feels Just Right

content: Marathoners are the NASCAR racers of running, trying to keep their radiators from boiling over during 26.2 miles and more than two hours on the road. Sprinters don’t have the same worries about heat and humidity. They are dragsters, generating massive power and searing speed then pulling the parachute in seconds.

title: Why Tunisia’s Promise of Democracy Struggles to Bear Fruit
description: The revolution of 2011 ousted a dictator and set off the Arab Spring. But then the West overlooked the country’s economic problems, intent on creating a bulwark against Islamist extremism.
content: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — In the 10 years since its popular uprising set off the Arab Spring, Tunisia has often been praised as the one success story to emerge from that era of turbulence. It rejected extremism and open warfare, it averted a counterrevolution, and its civic leaders even won a Nobel Peace Prize for consensus building.

Most of the single-family homes in the enclave were constructed in the last 15 years by a custom builder, who also worked with a local architect on the renovation of this property, from 2006 to 2009. content: As someone then working in a menial capacity on musicals, I was lucky enough to see the original production of James Lapine and Stephen Sondheim’s “Sunday in the Park With George” several times: once during its ragged, unfinished Off Broadway workshop at Playwrights Horizons in 1983 and repeatedly during its gleamingly polished Broadway run at the Booth Theater starting the next year. Either way, I thought it was a work of beauty and genius, especially after getting to study the music up close as I proofread parts of the score for the show’s copyist. What I didn’t know was how close, and how often, “Sunday” had come to not working at all.

title: Corrections: July 28, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 28, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about extreme weather in England misstated part of a warning issued by the Fire Brigade. The Fire Brigade warned that generators used to dry out old buildings could have released carbon monoxide, not carbon dioxide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Summer Pizza Party
description: Riff with your favorite sweet, salty and spicy toppings.
content: Good morning. We had a break in the heat and humidity and the kids wanted pizza and I realized that for all the recipes for pizza (above) I have, the only really important one is for dough. Everything else can be a riff, an improvisation, a no-recipe recipe. Just go easy on the toppings and strive for balance in the flavors: sweet against salty against spicy against bitter.
source.name: The New York Times
